available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.
available.name: Year Round

description:
Rich in color and character, our robust porter conjures up memories of decadent chocolate treats dipped in coffee. Hints of dark chocolate, roasted coffee and light malty sweetness are the result of a complex malt profile including chocolate malt, roasted barley, roasted wheat and roasted rye.

Silver medal in the Robust Porter category at the 2014 World Beer Cup®

style.description: Robust porters are black in color and have a roast malt flavor, often reminiscent of cocoa, but no roast barley flavor. These porters have a sharp bitterness of black malt without a highly burnt/charcoal flavor. Caramel and other malt sweetness should be present and in harmony with other distinguishing porter characters. Robust porters range from medium to full in body and have a malty sweetness. Hop bitterness is medium to high, with hop aroma and flavor ranging from negligible to medium. Diacetyl is acceptable at very low levels. Fruity esters should be evident, balanced with roast malt and hop bitterness.
style.name: Robust Porter

name: Stoup Robust Porter

style.description: Initial low to medium malt sweetness with a degree of caramel, chocolate and/or roasted coffee flavor with a distinctive dryroasted bitterness in the finish. Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Some slight roasted malt acidity is permissible and a medium- to full-bodied mouthfeel is appropriate. Hop bitterness may be moderate to high. Hop aroma and flavor is moderate to high, often with American citrus-type and/or resiny hop character. The perception of fruity esters is low. Roasted malt/barley astringency may be low but not excessive. Diacetyl (butterscotch) should be negligible or not perceived. Head retention is excellent.
style.name: American-Style Stout

style.description: Initial low to medium malt sweetness with a degree of caramel, chocolate and/or roasted coffee flavor with a distinctive dryroasted bitterness in the finish. Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Some slight roasted malt acidity is permissible and a medium- to full-bodied mouthfeel is appropriate. Hop bitterness may be moderate to high. Hop aroma and flavor is moderate to high, often with American citrus-type and/or resiny hop character. The perception of fruity esters is low. Roasted malt/barley astringency may be low but not excessive. Diacetyl (butterscotch) should be negligible or not perceived. Head retention is excellent.
style.name: American-Style Stout

style.description: As with classic dry stouts, foreign-style stouts have an initial malt sweetness and caramel flavor with a distinctive dry-roasted bitterness in the finish. Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Some slight acidity is permissible and a medium- to full-bodied mouthfeel is appropriate. Bitterness may be high but the perception is often compromised by malt sweetness. Hop aroma and flavor should not be perceived. The perception of fruity esters is low. Diacetyl (butterscotch) should be negligible or not perceived. Head retention is excellent.
style.name: Foreign (Export)-Style Stout

description: Our darkest ale is brewed in the famous Irish Dry Stout style. We use dark roasted malts and imported English East Kent Golding Hops. Served at our pub with nitrogen for a truly classic presentation. A bronze medal winner at the Great American Beer Festival.

style.description: As with classic dry stouts, foreign-style stouts have an initial malt sweetness and caramel flavor with a distinctive dry-roasted bitterness in the finish. Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Some slight acidity is permissible and a medium- to full-bodied mouthfeel is appropriate. Bitterness may be high but the perception is often compromised by malt sweetness. Hop aroma and flavor should not be perceived. The perception of fruity esters is low. Diacetyl (butterscotch) should be negligible or not perceived. Head retention is excellent.
style.name: Foreign (Export)-Style Stout

name: Stout

description: The strong presence of dark chocolate is nicely balanced with hints of roasted barley and english hops. A warming stout that will age beautifully in a bourbon barrel (winter '16).

style.description: Initial low to medium malt sweetness with a degree of caramel, chocolate and/or roasted coffee flavor with a distinctive dryroasted bitterness in the finish. style.name: American-Style Stout

description: A classic dry style stout. A healthy dose of roasted barley makes for a refreshingly simple, balanced stout.

style.description: Dry stouts have an initial malt and light caramel flavor profile with a distinctive dry-roasted bitterness in the finish. Dry stouts achieve a dry-roasted character through the use of roasted barley. The emphasis of coffee-like roasted barley and a moderate degree of roasted malt aromas define much of the character. Some slight acidity may be perceived but is not necessary. European hop aroma and flavor should be low or not perceived. Dry stouts have medium-light to medium body. Fruity esters are minimal and overshadowed by malt, high hop bitterness, and roasted barley character. Diacetyl (butterscotch) should be very low or not perceived. Head retention and rich character should be part of its visual character.
style.name: Classic Irish-Style Dry Stout

name: Stout

style.description: Initial low to medium malt sweetness with a degree of caramel, chocolate and/or roasted coffee flavor with a distinctive dryroasted bitterness in the finish. Hop bitterness may be moderate to high. Hop aroma and flavor is moderate to high, often with American citrus-type and/or resiny hop character. The perception of fruity esters is low. Roasted malt/barley astringency may be low but not excessive. Diacetyl (butterscotch) should be negligible or not perceived. Head retention is excellent.
style.name: American-Style Stout

description: A generous amount of chocolate and black malts and roasted barley are used to make a robust, full-bodied English style stout.  On-tap nitrogen creates a thick, creamy head and smooth finish.

name: Stout

description: Rich, dark beer.  Taste of coffee and chocolate from 4 varieties of malt, 2-row brewers malt, English Chocolate, black malt and roasted barley.  Great hop flavor and aroma from Liberty and East Kent Goldings Hops.  Smooth, what a Stout should be.

description: Creamy, robust, Irish-style dry stout. Full of flavors from deep roasted barley malts with a slight hint of chocolate. This is a beer for those who desire a big taste.

description: Velvety black and perfectly opaque, this surprisingly smooth, drinkable beer is a delightful harmony of roasted and malted barleys.  Flavors of cocoa and coffee abound in this limited production brew.

description:
Is there a more appropriately named beer style than stout? Dark, robust, opaquely possessive of heady aromas and rich fulfilling flavor, its name defines its assets. Ours is brewed with layers of roasted barley and black malts, and just enough flavor hops for a balanced smooth finish. By any definition, a superior beer.
Also available aged in bourbon barrels.

description: Do you like coffee?  How about chocolate? Cream?  This beer tastes like all of them at the same time, with a balanced finishe of hop and roast.  This is my best homebrew recipe for an American Stout.  Enjoy the dark!

description: Another classic British creation, although the history is a bit sketchy, we will say that stout is a stronger version of a porter (another beer style) characterized by relatively large amounts of roasted barley and/or black malt making the brew very dark and giving it a roast bitterness with coffee–like and chocolate flavors. Our stout uses the addition of oats and brown sugar for added complexity.

style.description: Dark copper to very dark brown, British-style imperial stouts typically have high alcohol content. The extremely rich malty flavor (often characterized as toffee-like or caramel-like) and aroma are balanced with medium hopping and high fruity-ester characteristics. Bitterness should be moderate and balanced with sweet malt character. The bitterness may be higher in the darker versions. Roasted malt astringency is very low or absent. Bitterness should not overwhelm the overall character. Hop aroma can be subtle to moderately hop-floral, -citrus or -herbal. Diacetyl (butterscotch) levels should be absent.
style.name: British-Style Imperial Stout

Some slight acidity may be perceived but is not necessary. European hop aroma and flavor should be low or not perceived. Dry stouts have medium-light to medium body. description:
The very first beer we brewed at Little Toad Creek was an Oatmeal Stout. We use Biscuit malt to give a roasty 
malt flavor that works well with the oats. Only slightly sweet, this Stout gets it just right!

description: Creamy, malty, and full-bodied, the Stout is satisfyingly rich. Caramel and black malts give the Stout its deep, dark color and pronounced roasted flavor, balanced by a smooth hop flavor.

description: Burnside Stout is brewed with imported Simpson malts and East Kent Golding hops. Our Stout features bold notes of coffee and chocolate, with a dry roasty finish. Notice the beautiful thick brown head and deep opaque color. Pair it equally well with a main course of meat, or a dessert of chocolate.

description: Modeled after a Russian Imperial Stout, this ale is robust and full-bodied with a coffee and espresso flavor profile.  Complex and intensely black, this stout has rich, deep dark fruity esters.  Strong and roasty with a smooth mouth-feel.

description: Most everyone has heard of this style, even if they haven’t tried it.  Our version is a traditional dry Stout, found in the southern part of Ireland.  It’s dark, drinkable and definitely true to style.

style.description: Initial low to medium malt sweetness with a degree of caramel, chocolate and/or roasted coffee flavor with a distinctive dryroasted bitterness in the finish. name: Stout

style.description: Black in color, American-style imperial stouts typically have a high alcohol content. Generally characterized as very robust. The extremely rich malty flavor and aroma are balanced with assertive hopping and fruity-ester characteristics. Bitterness should be moderately high to very high and balanced with full sweet malt character. Roasted malt astringency and bitterness can be moderately perceived but should not overwhelm the overall character. Hop aroma is usually moderately-high to overwhelmingly hop-floral, -citrus or -herbal. Diacetyl (butterscotch) levels should be absent.
style.name: American-Style Imperial Stout

description: A silky smooth, full-body beer with a sturdy black color. This beer features a mild bitterness with hints of roasted caramel and chocolate for a true taste sensation. A slight coffee taste in the finish.

description: Black as night with ruby highlights…so sexy. This stout is both roasty and sweet. Bigger versions of this hoppy stout will be found hanging out in barrels around our brewery.

description: Saddlebock stout is distinctively dark with a creamy texture, and a rich, full flavor. Complex grain notes carry just a hint of molasses. This is the perfect beer to warm you up on a cold day.

name: Stout

description: Crystal and light caramel malts combine with a heavy dose of roasted barley to lay the base for the Mt. Hood and East Kent Golding hops. This is designed to be an easy drinking beer. Not too bitter, not too sweet, this dark beer finishes just dry enough to have you coming back.

style.description: Initial low to medium malt sweetness with a degree of caramel, chocolate and/or roasted coffee flavor with a distinctive dryroasted bitterness in the finish. Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Some slight roasted malt acidity is permissible and a medium- to full-bodied mouthfeel is appropriate. Hop bitterness may be moderate to high. Hop aroma and flavor is moderate to high, often with American citrus-type and/or resiny hop character. The perception of fruity esters is low. Roasted malt/barley astringency may be low but not excessive. Diacetyl (butterscotch) should be negligible or not perceived. Head retention is excellent.
style.name: American-Style Stout

available.name: Seasonal

description: A quaffable, malty, drier stout highlighted by Crystal 120, Roasted, Chocolate malts and flaked oats.

name: Stout

description: A West Coast Stout brewed with of crystal malt, roasted barley, black malt, and hopped with the ever so lovely Cascade Hop. The roast flavours and aromas are complimented by floral and spicy hop characters. The perfect beer for the winter months.
